form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Ms. Cantwell introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources

form.official-title: To require the Secretary of Energy to conduct a study on the technology, potential lifecycle energy savings, and economic impact of recycled carbon fiber, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Carbon Fiber Recycling Act of 2015.

paragraph.text: current methods for manufacturing carbon fiber are energy intensive, making carbon fiber costly for use in mass-produced applications;
it takes approximately one-tenth the energy to produce recycled carbon fiber as it does to produce virgin carbon fiber;
using recycled carbon fiber in the manufacturing process could result in as great as 40 percent in cost savings compared to the manufacture of virgin fiber; and
up to 30 percent of carbon fiber manufactured becomes part of the waste stream.

subsection.text: The Secretary of Energy (referred to in this Act as the Secretary) shall conduct a study on—

paragraph.text: the technology of recycled carbon fiber and production waste carbon fiber; and
the potential lifecycle energy savings and economic impact of recycled carbon fiber.

subsection.text: In conducting the study under subsection (b), the Secretary shall consider—

paragraph.text: the quantity of recycled carbon fiber or production waste carbon fiber that would make the use of recycled carbon fiber or production waste carbon fiber economically viable;
any existing or potential barriers to recycling carbon fiber or using recycled carbon fiber;
any financial incentives that may be necessary for the development of recycled carbon fiber or production waste carbon fiber;
the potential lifecycle savings in energy from producing recycled carbon fiber, as compared to producing new carbon fiber;
the best and highest use for recycled carbon fiber;
the potential reduction in carbon dioxide emissions from producing recycled carbon fiber, as compared to producing new carbon fiber;
any economic benefits gained from using recycled carbon fiber or production waste carbon fiber;
workforce training and skills needed to address labor demands in the development of recycled carbon fiber or production waste carbon fiber; and
how the Department of Energy can leverage existing efforts in the industry on the use of production waste carbon fiber.

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall submit to Congress a report describing the results of the study conducted under subsection (b).

section.text: The Secretary shall consult with the aviation and automotive industries and existing programs of the Advanced Manufacturing Office of the Department of Energy to develop a carbon fiber recycling demonstration project.
There is authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary to carry out this Act $10,000,000, to remain available until expended.
